awd_abstract_narration:
The Subduction Zone Observatories (SZO) concept is a multidisciplinary facility and associated science program to study a significant portion of one or more of the circum-Pacific/Caribbean subduction zones as an integrated system. Subduction zones contain a rich diversity of tectonic processes operating at a wide range of temporal and spatial scales, from plate-scale over millions of years to grain-scale over microseconds. Subduction zones span continental to oceanic environments, and interact with biological processes and climate. Subduction zones are responsible for many of Earth's most extreme natural events including earthquakes, volcanic eruptions,
and tsunamis. These hazards coupled with increasing population density in these regions leads to an urgent need to understand how subduction zones work to better inform hazard assessment, mitigation, forecasting, and early warning. Emerging technologies, strong international partnerships, open access data, and the success of long-term community experiments supported by EarthScope and MARGINS/GeoPRISMS establish a strong foundation to investigate the entire subduction zone system from an integrated, multidisciplinary perspective and at multiple scales.

A Subduction Zone Observatory workshop will provide a critical forum to build community consensus across a range of disciplines and constituencies, and an opportunity for early career scientists and senior graduate students to help shape a new transformative initiative. A systems approach to the study of subduction zone processes promotes integration across multiple disciplines, interagency and international collaboration and partnerships, technological innovation, early career development, education and training for graduate students including students from underrepresented groups, and improved hazard assessment.

por.por_cntn:
Subduction zones are Earth’s most tectonically dynamic regions and hold the key to understanding many of its most fundamental processes, such as how mountain uplift and climate interact to form landscapes, cycling of water and carbon dioxide through the Earth’s mantle, reemission of these gases through volcanoes, and the myriad of influences on the style of faulting within and between the tectonic plates. Through these processes they also produce devastating earthquakes, tsunamis, volcanic eruptions, and landslides in many cases near heavily populated regions. Despite the enormous social significance of these hazards and their worldwide scope, many of the basic physical and chemical processes that control the occurrence and magnitude of these natural events remain poorly understood.

 

Advances in offshore and satellite observations could now record the run-up to earthquakes and eruptions. New high rate data sets near faults and on volcanoes provide geochemical, hydrological, geophysical, and geological observations that, when assimilated, will improve dynamic, predictive models. Laboratory experiments are now able to measure the behavior of material in faults and under volcanoes, and new chemical timekeepers are constraining rates of processes from minutes to millions of years. These technological advances, combined with observations that can be integrated over a broad range of spatial and temporal scales, provide the impetus for a new, interdisciplinary, coordinated program to better understand subduction phenomena. To establish a framework for such a program, this award supported a workshop and associated activities that allowed more than 250 scientists from 22 countries to meet and present a range of perspectives. This included discussion of high-priority science targets, critical gaps that are holding back subduction zone science, mechanisms for interdisciplinary in-reach and capacity-building outreach, and ways to coordinate and leverage various academic, national agency, and international resources.

 

This has led to developing a formal vision for a new effort focused on the integration of data sets and models that capture the four-dimensional (4D) evolution of subduction processes that lead to geohazards and evolution of the solid Earth and its surface. The SZ4D Initiative seeks to move subduction science from describing static snapshots to fully capturing and modeling key phenomena as they evolve both in real time and through geological time. SZ4D will enable frontier observational activities that are impossible or difficult to do now. Three key components—a modeling collaboratory, an interdisciplinary science program, and a community infrastructure program—were identified at the workshop that, in combination over 10 years, could help realize the vision for a deeper understanding of subduction zone systems in the United States and around the world. There are existing programs run by multiple US agencies, including NSF, USGS, NASA, and NOAA, and numerous international organizations that already provide a strong foundation for this. The SZ4D Initiative will present a new opportunity to coordinate efforts across agencies and with international partners. In this report, we develop the scientific motivations and present a vision for the frontier opportunities and key ingredients of a new SZ4D Initiative.

Whitepapers, webinars, and the final SZ4D Initiative report may be found here: https://www.iris.edu/hq/workshops/2016/09/szo_16/
